The Ground of Wonderful Goodness, the Ninth
When the Buddha's disciples expounded the wonderful meaning of the eighth ground,
By the Buddha's spiritual power, countless lands trembled.
The body of omniscience emitted immeasurable subtle light,
Illuminating the worlds in the ten directions, bringing peace and happiness to sentient beings.
Countless myriads of bodhisattvas dwelled in the sky,
Arranging wondrous offerings that even the devas do not have.
The great sovereign king and the king of the god realm of transforming others,
Joyfully made wondrous offerings to the Buddha of Great Ocean of Merits.
Countless thousands of celestial maidens, respectfully delighted,
With the same subtle voice, sang praises of the Buddha's merits:
By the Buddha's spiritual power, such wonderful Dharma emerges,
Those who skillfully practice quiescence have no evil thoughts.
Each abiding in their own stage, skillfully cultivating bodhisattva practices,
In order to benefit the world, they roam everywhere in the ten directions.
Demonstrating the Buddha's path to the assembly, their minds are unobstructed like space,
The spiritual powers of the bodhisattvas, the supreme offerings,
Surpass those of the humans and gods of the ten directions, attained through merit and virtue,
The Buddha's disciples who delight in wisdom use this to demonstrate the Buddha's power.
In one country, without moving, they manifest in all places,
Benefiting the world, like the bright and pure full moon.
Destroying all sounds, speech, and thoughts,
Yet using various sounds to expound the Dharma, like an echo.
According to the inferior beings whose minds are weary and overwhelmed,
They demonstrate and expound the ÅšrÄvaka Path, enabling them to escape from the many sufferings;
For any sentient beings with dull faculties,
Who delight in the Dharma of causes and conditions, they expound the pratyekabuddha path;
For any beings with sharp faculties who benefit others,
With a mind of great compassion, they expound the bodhisattva Dharma.
If there are those with the supreme great mind, who definitely delight in great matters,
They reveal the Buddha's body and expound the immeasurable Buddha Dharma.
Just as an illusionist displays various bodily forms,
All those bodily characteristics are ultimately unreal.
In the same way, the Buddha's disciples skillfully understand the methods of wisdom,
And are able to reveal all practices, their minds free from existence and nonexistence.
Countless celestial maidens sing praises with subtle voices,
Having sung praises in this way, they silently gaze upon the Buddha.
Furthermore, Samantabhadra said:
Buddha's disciples!
The great assembly is pure, single-mindedly wishing to hear the correct practices beyond the eighth ground.
Vajra Treasury Bodhisattva said:
Buddha's disciple!

The bodhisattvas dwelling in this ground know as it truly is the practices of arising good, bad, and neutral dharmas, the practices of contaminated and uncontaminated dharmas, worldly and supramundane dharmas, conceivable and inconceivable dharmas, determined and undetermined dharmas, the practices of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, the practices of the bodhisattva path and the stage of the tathÄgatas, and the practices of conditioned and unconditioned dharmas.

In accordance with such wisdom, they know the difficulties of the practices of the enlightened mind, the difficulties of afflictions, the difficulties of karma, the difficulties of faculties, the difficulties of aspirations, the difficulties of natures, the difficulties of resolute minds, the difficulties of profound minds, the difficulties of birth, the difficulties of residual energies, and the difficulties of the distinctions among the three groups.

They know the various aspects of the minds of sentient beings, the mixed aspects of the mind, the light and fleeting aspects of the mind, the aspects of the mind's destruction and non-destruction, the formless aspects of the mind, the boundless and all-pervading aspects of the mind, the aspects of the mind's purity and distinctions, the aspects of the mind's defilements, the aspects of the mind's non-defilements, the aspects of the mind's bondage, the aspects of the mind's liberation, the aspects of the mind's crookedness, and the aspects of the mind's straightforwardness, and the aspects of the mind's conformity with the path, all of which they know as they truly are.

This bodhisattva knows the profound aspects of afflictions and the shallow aspects, knows the aspects of the mind accompanying afflictions and the inseparable aspects, knows the aspects of the distinctions of the bonds and entanglements, knows the aspects of being associated with and not associated with the mind, knows the aspects of obtaining the fruits of retribution when arising, knows the aspects of the distinctions within the three realms, knows the aspects of the deep penetration of craving, ignorance, and views like an arrow, knows the aspects of the grave offenses of arrogance, ignorance, and heavy sins, and knows the aspects of the causes and conditions of the three karmas that are uninterrupted. In brief, he knows up to the aspects of entering the eighty-four thousand distinctions in the practices of afflictions as they truly are.
This bodhisattva knows the characteristics of good, bad, and neutral karma, the characteristics of distinction and non-distinction,

the characteristics of being accompanied by the mind, the characteristics of inseparability, the characteristics of natural exhaustion, the characteristics of exhausting the path of practice, the characteristics of seeds,

the characteristics of accumulation, the characteristics of not losing karmic retribution, the characteristics of sequence, the characteristics of having retribution, the characteristics of having no retribution, the characteristics of black karma with black retribution, the characteristics of white karma with white retribution, the characteristics of black and white karma with black and white retribution,

the characteristics of karma that is neither black nor white and can exhaust karma, the characteristics of knowing the origin of karma, the characteristics of the distinctions in the Dharma of receiving karma,

the characteristics of knowing karma arising from immeasurable causes and conditions, the characteristics of the distinctions between worldly and supramundane karma, the characteristics of immediate retribution, the characteristics of retribution in the next life, the characteristics of retribution in future lives, the characteristics of following various karmas with certainty,
the characteristics of uncertainty, in brief, up to accurately knowing the characteristics of the eighty-four thousand distinctions in karma.

This bodhisattva knows the characteristics of the soft, medium, and sharp faculties, the characteristics of the distinctions between the past and future, the characteristics of non-distinction, the characteristics of superior, medium, and inferior, the characteristics of the companions of afflictions, the characteristics of non-separation, the characteristics of determination according to the vehicles, the characteristics of non-determination, the characteristics of maturity, the characteristics of immaturity, the characteristics of following mental activities, the characteristics of easy destruction, the characteristics of deep grasping, the characteristics of supremacy, the characteristics of indestructibility, the characteristics of transformation, the characteristics of non-transformation, the characteristics of distinctions in the three times, and the characteristics of the distinctions of the deeply hidden co-arising. In brief, he knows the characteristics of the distinctions of the eighty-four thousand faculties as they really are.

This bodhisattva knows the characteristics of the soft, medium, and sharp desires and pleasures of sentient beings, and in brief, he knows the characteristics of the distinctions of the eighty-four thousand desires and pleasures as they really are.

This bodhisattva knows the characteristics of deep, middling, and sharp minds, and in brief, he knows the characteristics of the eighty-four thousand differences in deep minds.

This bodhisattva distinguishes and knows the various afflictions, which arise with companions and without companions, are associated with the mind and not associated with the mind, have deep characteristics, have harmed sentient beings since beginningless time, are contrary to all meditations, liberations, and spiritual powers, are firmly bound, are bound to the three realms without being manifest, open the doors to various karmas, have characteristics that cannot be known and opposed, have characteristics of non-existence, have characteristics of indeterminate events, have characteristics that are not different from the noble path, and have characteristics of extinguishing agitation.

This bodhisattva knows the characteristics of the various differences in birth, namely the differences between hell, animals, hungry ghosts, asuras, humans, and gods, the differences between the form realm and formless realm, and the differences between having conceptual thoughts and having no conceptual thoughts.

Karma is the field, craving is the water, ignorance is the darkness, consciousness is the seed, the subsequent body is the sprout, name-and-form arise together but are not separate, there are the characteristics of deluded craving, the characteristics of continuity, the desire to be born, the desire to act, the desire to love, the characteristics of not leaving the desire for sentient beings, the characteristics of distinguishing the differences in the three realms, the characteristics of the continuity of the three existences, all of which are known as they truly are.

This bodhisattva truly knows the remaining and non-remaining habitual tendencies, the habitual tendencies that arise according to the place of birth, the habitual tendencies that accompany sentient beings, the habitual tendencies that follow karma and afflictions, the habitual tendencies of good, evil, and neutral, the habitual tendencies of detachment, the habitual tendencies that follow the subsequent body, and the habitual tendencies that follow in sequence.
He deeply enters the characteristics of cutting off the path, the characteristics of upholding afflictions, and the characteristics of being without anything to leave, all of which are truly known.

This bodhisattva truly knows the characteristics of sentient beings' definite and indefinite states, the characteristics of right and wrong definite states, the characteristics of wrong views and wrong definite states, and the characteristics of right views and right definite states, and the characteristics of no definite state apart from these two.

The characteristics of each of the five heinous crimes are wrong definite states, and the characteristics of the five roots are right definite states. Wrong position is wrong definite, and right position is right definite, because one does not commit them again. The characteristics of the indefinite state are apart from these two states.

Deeply entering the difficult-to-transform characteristics of the group of wrong views, the characteristics of the causes and conditions for cultivating the unsurpassed path, the group of indefinite states, the group of wrong definite states, and the characteristics of the protection of sentient beings, he truly knows them all.
Buddha's disciple!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who follow such wisdom are called those who abide in the ground of good joy.

The bodhisattva who abides in this ground knows the characteristics of the distinctions in the practices of sentient beings in this way, and in accordance with their liberation, he bestows the causes and conditions.
This bodhisattva knows the Dharma for transforming sentient beings and knows the Dharma for liberating sentient beings. He knows as it truly is and expounds the Dharma for them.

He knows as it truly is the characteristics of the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle, the characteristics of the Pratyekabuddha Vehicle, the characteristics of the Bodhisattva Vehicle, and the characteristics of the TathÄgata Ground, and expounds the Dharma for sentient beings according to their causes and conditions.
He expounds the Dharma according to their minds, faculties, and distinctions in desires and pleasures;
and he expounds the Dharma according to their places of practice and places of wisdom.
He knows all places of practice and expounds the Dharma accordingly;
he expounds the Dharma according to the natures of sentient beings and their difficult places to enter deeply;
he expounds the Dharma according to the turning of the path, birth, afflictions, and habitual tendencies;
and he expounds the Dharma in order to liberate according to the vehicles.

This bodhisattva, dwelling in this ground, becomes a great Dharma master, guarding the Dharma treasury of the buddhas. He falls into the profound and wonderful meaning of the great Dharma master and uses immeasurable wisdom and skillful means, the four unobstructed understandings, and the bodhisattva's verbal expressions to expound the Dharma.
This bodhisattva always follows the four unobstructed understandings without discrimination.
What are the four?

First, the unobstructed understanding of dharmas; second, the unobstructed understanding of meanings; third, the unobstructed understanding of languages; fourth, the unobstructed understanding of eloquence.

This bodhisattva uses the unobstructed understanding of dharmas to know the self-characteristics of all dharmas; uses the unobstructed understanding of meanings to know the distinctions among all dharmas; uses the unobstructed understanding of languages to know the non-discriminating explanations of all dharmas; uses the unobstructed understanding of eloquence to know the uninterrupted sequence of all dharmas.

Furthermore, using the unobstructed understanding of dharmas, one knows that all dharmas have no essence; using the unobstructed understanding of meanings, one knows the characteristics of the arising and ceasing of all dharmas; using the unobstructed understanding of languages, one knows the provisional names of all dharmas and explains without cutting off the provisional names; using the unobstructed understanding of eloquence, one follows the provisional names and explains without destroying the boundless.

Furthermore, with unobstructed knowledge of dharmas one knows the characteristics of presently existing dharmas, with unobstructed knowledge of meanings one knows the characteristics of past and future dharmas, with unobstructed knowledge of expression one knows how to explain past, future, and presently existing dharmas without discrimination, and with unobstructed knowledge of eloquence one is able to explain them because one attains boundless characteristics of dharmas in each of the three periods of time.

Furthermore, with unobstructed knowledge of dharmas one knows the distinctions among dharmas, with unobstructed knowledge of meanings one knows the distinctions in the meanings of dharmas, with unobstructed knowledge of expression one teaches the Dharma according to the various languages and sounds, and with unobstructed knowledge of eloquence one teaches the Dharma according to the various understandings and preferences.

Furthermore, with unobstructed knowledge of dharmas one knows the distinctions among dharmas through the knowledge of dharmas, and one knows that all dharmas are without distinctions through skillful means;
with unobstructed knowledge of meanings one knows the distinctions among dharmas as they really are through inferential knowledge;
with unobstructed knowledge of expression one teaches the distinctions among dharmas through worldly knowledge;
Using the unobstructed understanding of eloquence, one knows how to skillfully expound the ultimate truth.
Furthermore, using the unobstructed understanding of dharmas, one knows that all dharmas are of one characteristic and indestructible;
Using the unobstructed understanding of meaning, one skillfully enters the aggregates, sense bases, elements, truths, and dependent origination;
Using the unobstructed understanding of language, one becomes the object of all worldly beings, due to having a subtle voice;
Using the unobstructed understanding of eloquence, one's explanations become increasingly superior, enabling sentient beings to attain boundless illumination of the Dharma.
Furthermore, using the unobstructed understanding of dharmas, one knows that all dharmas are without discrimination and are subsumed within the One Vehicle;
Using the unobstructed understanding of meaning, one enters the gateway of discriminating the distinctions of all dharmas;
Using the unobstructed understanding of language, one is able to explain the meaning of the non-discrimination of all vehicles;
Using the unobstructed understanding of eloquence, one explains boundless illumination of the Dharma using a single Dharma door.
Furthermore, using the unobstructed understanding of dharmas, one is able to enter all bodhisattva practices, practices of wisdom, practices of dharmas, and practices in accordance with wisdom;
Using the unobstructed understanding of meaning, one can distinguish and explain the differences in the meaning of the ten grounds;
Using the unobstructed understanding of expression, one can explain in accordance with the various grounds without discrimination;
Using the unobstructed understanding of eloquence, one can explain the boundless characteristics of all practices.

Furthermore, using the unobstructed understanding of dharmas, one knows that all Buddhas attain enlightenment in a single thought; using the unobstructed understanding of meaning, one knows the differences in various times and places; using the unobstructed understanding of expression, one explains the differences in the events of the Buddhas attaining the Way; using the unobstructed understanding of eloquence, one explains a single phrase of the Dharma for boundless eons without exhausting it.

Furthermore, using the unobstructed understanding of dharmas, one knows the teachings of all Buddhas, the powers, fearlessnesses, unique qualities, great compassion, unobstructed understanding, turning the wheel of the Dharma, and so forth, in accordance with omniscience;

Using the unobstructed understanding of meaning, one follows the sounds of the TathÄgata's voice, which produces eighty-four thousand, in accordance with the minds of sentient beings, their faculties, and their differences in desires and pleasures;
Using unobstructed eloquence, he expounds all practices with the voice of the TathÄgata without discrimination;
Using unobstructed eloquence in expounding, he expounds according to the sounds that beings delight in with the wisdom and power of the buddhas.
Buddha's disciples!

This bodhisattva, if all the sentient beings in the trichiliocosm were to ask questions simultaneously, and if each sentient being were to ask with immeasurable and boundless different sounds, and if each question were different from the others, this bodhisattva would in a single thought accept all these questions and answer them all with a single sound.

Just as with a single hair-tip, all worlds in the ten directions are also like this. One should give rise to the power of great mindfulness, and in a single thought, receive all Dharma-illuminations from all buddhas without losing a single phrase.

If the sentient beings filling the great assemblies listen to the Dharma, or if in this way, with the Dharma-illumination of definitive purity, one expounds and causes them to attain understanding, causing that many sentient beings to all attain joy in a single thought, how much more so for the sentient beings in innumerable worlds?

The bodhisattva who abides in this stage, his wholesome roots become even more excellent. Day and night, he has no other thoughts. He deeply enters the realm of the buddhas' practice, always encountering all buddhas, and deeply enters the bodhisattva's liberation.
